awd_titl_txt: Dead Sea Water Workshop 2019: Separations and transport in nanomaterials and confined nanochannels
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide partial travel support for 13 U.S.-based postdoctoral researchers and graduate students to attend the 2019 Dead Sea Water Workshop in Ein Gide, Israel on February 4-7, 2019. The first offering of this thematic meeting will be devoted to discussions on recent developments and emerging trends in nanofluidic phenomena and materials, including separation and transport phenomena in nanoscale channels and pores. The meeting intends to achieve three main objectives: (1) to educate students on water scarcity and current challenges facing society; (2) to disseminate the latest research results on the physics of transport at the nanoscale; and (3) to grow a research community concerned with developing and utilizing new materials and phenomena for next-generation water-purification devices. The discussion-rich format of the meeting, alongside the engaging lineup of invited speakers, will provide a vibrant and enriching experience for professional development. The workshop location provides a unique opportunity for students and scientists to explore an operating wastewater treatment facility that is actively piloting water reuse technologies. Additionally, enabling U.S.-based researchers to interact with Israeli counterparts serves to build and strengthen international research infrastructure.

The Dead Sea Workshop organizing committee is comprised of both American and Israeli researchers, and invited speakers from the U.S. and Europe feature prominently in the program. The workshop will feature 10 technical sessions, two poster sessions, an organized pilot facility tour, and abundant unstructured discussion periods to catalyze new collaborative relationships and research ideas. The 2019 Dead Sea Water Workshop will focus, specifically, on the following topics: (1) fundamentals of fluid flow and confinement on water transport in nanochannels and nanostructures; (2) phase transitions and equilibria in nanoscale pores and channels; (3) mechanism of ion transport and ion selectivity in nanoscale pores; (4) theory and modeling approaches for understanding nanofluidic and electrosorption phenomena; and (5) carbon and related nanomaterials for novel membrane technologies and electrochemical separations. The topic of the new meeting is unique amongst existing conferences and workshops that more broadly focus on membrane science. Furthermore, the style of the workshop will encourage meaningful interactions between junior and senior researchers and provides opportunities for in-depth discussion and professional development. The award of travel subsidies is expected to attract young, diverse scientists to a meeting they may not otherwise be able to attend.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
TAHOE Nanofluidics 2022 took place in the North Tahoe region on May 23-27, 2022. The meeting featured 50 participants from US, Europe, and Asia (Israel, Singapore). The conference program covered a variety of topics in nanofluidics and featured 24 oral presentations and 10 poster presentations that took over the span of three days (see attached schedule and program for details). A variety of activities during the afternoon free time blocks also contributed to the community building efforts and provided a venue for numerous unstructured discussions between the participants.

Scientific outcome. The meeting has played a significant role in establishing the community around nanofluidics. Discussions at the conference allowed researchers to identify the most promising new directions as well as the areas tyat we as a community need to pay attention to. The meeting also generated several new collaborations. One of the kost important aspects of the meeting was that it gavce students an ample opportunity to interact with senior faculty, ask questiosn, and exchange ideas. The meeting was also an ideal setting for networking and career development. 

Meeting safety. The conference program, venue and schedule were designed with maximum COVID safety in mind (enhanced ventilation in the meeting room, meals served outside whenever possible). The organizers also made available KN95 and surgical facemasks for those who wanted to use them and had a supply of rapid COVID tests on-site in case. We are proud to report that there was no COVID cases reported during the meeting and no COVID cases have been linked to the meeting after it has finished. 

Poster prizes. The conference awarded two student poster prizes sponsored by Nature Nanotechnology and Nature Water.  The prizes were awarded by the senior academics jury composed of Dr. Frances Allen (UC Berkeley), Dr. Marija Drndic (U.Penn), Dr. Baoxia Mi (UC Berkeley), and Dr. Slaven Garaj (NTU Singapore). The Nature Water Prize went to Mohammed Heiranian (Yale) and the Nature Nanotechnology prize went to Philippe Nicolier (ETH Zurich) (Figure 2).

Conference survey results. After the conference, all participants were asked to fill a survey that measured participants’ satisfaction with conference topics, program, accommodation, food, and afternoon activities. The post-conference survey gave the overall meeting high marks (Figure 3). In particular, 80% of the participants responses said that the meeting exceeded their expectations. No responses expressed dissatisfaction with the meeting. The conference also received high scores on the quality and diversity of the scientific program (see Figure 1 for survey results). Moreover, 100% of respondents indicated that they want this meeting to continue as an on-going biannual conference.


Last Modified: 05/16/2023
Modified by: Aleksandr Noy
